SafetyInspectionBy: IOWA DEPT. OF AGRICULTURE & Land Stewardship

_prev_prog_2.FR_Comments: State of Iowa, Agriculture & Land Stewardship Department [21] Chapter 43 Fertilizers & Agricultural
_prev_prog_2.PC_OtherType: Administrative controls (operation procedures in place, speed limit, etc.) and load-out riser breakaway system.
_prev_prog_2.MD_OtherType: Routine visual inspections by trained operators
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Storage Tanks, and associated piping and transfer equipment.
_prev_prog_2.Description:
The primary activity at the facility is the distribution of products to area farmers. The fertilizer product, anhydrous ammonia is received, stored and distributed for direct application as a nutrient for crop production.



Employees, many who have been on the job for a number of years, working with anhydrous ammonia at our bulk storage and distribution facility, make routine inspections prior to and during transfer operations of anhydrous ammonia from the storage vessel(s) into nurse tanks.  This routine inspection identifies any potential concerns that may arise within the system.  If needed, repairs are made before they become problematic. 



All employees are trained upon initial hiring to recognize the hazards associated with storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia, and annually thereafter.  This training includes classroom instruction, oral testing, on-site training at the plant.  Employees new to working with anhydrous ammonia, also are observed to determine their individual comprehension and understanding when working with anhydrous ammonia. 



The company routinely invites local fire department personnel to visit the site.

_emerg_resp.FR_OtherRegulation: State of Iowa, Agriculture & Land Stewardship Department [21] Chapter 43 Fertilizers & Agricultural

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Plan - Executive Summary



Facility:  Cogdill Farm Supply, Inc.

    301 North Railway Street    

    Panama, IA  51562

Contact: Robert P. Cogdill

Phone:   712-489-2535



1.    Facility Policy.



        The owners, management and employees of Cogdill Farm Supply, Inc. are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, Shelby Emergency Management/County LEPC, and/or other authorities, to mitigate and minimize the impacts of the release to the people and the environment.



2.    Facility Information.



        The primary activity at the facility is the distribution of products to area farmers.  The fertilizer product, anhydrous ammonia is received, stored and distributed for direct application as a nutrient for crop production.  At times, Anhydrous ammonia is also stored on site in nurse tanks designed for this purpose.  The facility is manned year round during normal business hours.



3.    The Worst-Case Release Scenario and the Alternate Release Scenario 



         An analysis of the potential off-site consequences of hypothetical worst-case and alternative-case accidental releases have been addressed in our Hazard Assessment and information is in our Risk Management Program.



4.    Accidental Release Prevention Program



        The facility is in compliance with the provisions of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia" and state regulations covering anhydrous ammonia.  The OSHA standard is referenced in this RMP Registration Form; see Section 8.3 (b).



5.    Five-Year Accident History.



        There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that have caused any deaths, injuries or significant property damage at the facility; nor to our knowledge, has THERE BEEN ANY ACCIDENTAL RELEASES resulting

in off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, property damage, or environmental damage.



6.    Emergency Action Plan.



         The facility has:



          a.   A written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard

                29 CFR 1910.38;



          b.   Provided state and local authorities with the emergency planning and

                Community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III

                (EPCRA);



          c.   If a large release of anhydrous ammonia takes place at the facility,

                the required response action is to evacuate the area of the release and

                call 911 and all applicable emergency response numbers listed in our

                Emergency Action Plan.



7.    Planned Changes to Improve Safety.



        Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility.  Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the conditions at our facility.   There are no additional specific safety recommendations regarding storage or use of anhydrous ammonia for implementation at this time.
